intro.p: A reporter for a newspaper is doing an article about the cost of attending college. She collects the total annual cost for an in-state student (including tuition, fees, housing, and meals) from 4-year institutions in {{name_1}}, {{name_2}}, {{name_3}}. The three data sets are summarized below:

content.p: What is the {{min_max}} average annual cost a school in {{name_2}} could have and still be {{dir_1}} than {{percent_1}}\% of other schools in that dataset?
{{name_3}}'s dataset has a quartile {{quar_2}} of {{time_2}}. Explain what this means in terms of the average annual cost of attending a college in that state.

outtro.p: {{answer_2}}\% of {{name_3}}'s 4-year colleges have an average annual cost of {{time_2}} dollars or less.

content.p: Describe the shape of the distribution of that average annual cost of attending a 4-year college in {{name_1}}. Use evidence from the summary table.

outtro.p: Skewed right, needs to be justified

content.p: Afer looking at her data, the reporter realized that the most expensive college in {{name_3}} was a "for profit" college and did not want to include it in her report. If that data point was taken out of {{name_3}}'s' data, what would happen to the {{stat}} of it's dataset? Explain your answer.

outtro.p: It would go down, explanation needed
